 WHAT ACCOUNTS FOR THE DECLINE IN INFANT MORTALITY IN PENINSULAR MALAYSIA, 1946-1975? Julie DaVanzo Jean-Pierre Habicht

 Abstract The infant mortality rate has declined dramatically in Peninsular Malaysia since World War II. This study uses individual-level retrospective data on infant mortality and its correlates (from the Malaysian Family Life Survey) to examine possible reasons for this decline. One important factor has been the substantial increase in mothers' education. Improvements in water and sanitation also played a role; however, the reduction in breastfeeding that has taken place in Malaysia has kept the infant mortality rate from declining as rapidly as it would have otherwise. This paper shows that the detrimental effects of reduced breastfeeding have more than offset the beneficial effects of improvements in water and sanitation. In a majority of the cases, infant mortality decline is not explained by changes in the variables considered here, but is due to factors not investigated here--most likely, increases in income and improvements in medical and health care.  I. Introduction One of the more gratifying phenomena of the twentieth century has been the decline of mortality rates in general and of infant mortality in particular. Nearly three-quarters of the total increase in longevity in recorded history has occurred since 1900 (Preston 1976). Life expectancy at birth has doubled since the beginning of this century (Gwatkin 1980). Mortality declines have been greatest in developing countries, such as Malaysia. Since World War II, many of the countries have recorded gains in life expectancy at least three times as large as those achieved in Western Europe at a comparable stage in its mortality transition (Gwatkin 1980). As Gwatkin notes, "such rapid progress coming at such low initial levels of life expectancy was . . . quite without precedent in history" (p. 617). These mortality declines are the major reason for the rapid population growth in developing countries since World War II. Declining infant mortality explains much of the general decline in mortality. In most populations, more people die during the first year of life than at any other single age. For example, 28 percent of all deaths in Peninsular Malaysia in 1957 occurred in the first year of life (Malaysia Department of Statistics 1976). 1/ Furthermore, over the period of rapid mortality decline in developing countries, infant mortality rates have shown the largest absolute declines. In Malaysia, they have declined from about 100 infant deaths per 1000 live births in the 1940s to about 30 in the 1970s (Fig. 1). The sheer value of life aside, reducing infant mortality has high priority for developing countries because children are a major resource for both poor families and the nation, and because decreases in infant mortality usually lead to reductions in fertility. Consequently, Third

To do so, they need to know exactly what changes have contributed to this decline and what factors, if any, have kept the decline from being greater. Many hypotheses have been advanced to explain the dramatic declines in infant mortality. Like overall mortality, infant mortality is allegedly associated with socioeconomic development; programs to control communicable diseases; health education; and improvements in nutrition, sanitation, and medical ancl health care. However, some factors may have a particular effect on infant mortality. These include pre- and post-natal care, child health
 services, infant feeding, and family planning (which can promote proper spacing of children and reduce other high-risk births. Despite a pervasive sense that these factors do affect infant mortality, to our knowledge there have been no assessment of their relative roles in explaining declines. 2/ In this paper, we attempt to fill that gap in knowledge, using data on Malaysia from 1946 to 1975. During this period, Malaysia experienced rapid economic growth and profound social and demographic change, including the dramatic decline in infant mortality rates shown in Fig. 1. Our data, from the Malaysian Family Life Survey, are unique in that they (1) cover this period of dramatic change; (2) document not only infant mortality over this period, but also many of its key determinants, 3/ and (3) document these variables at the micro level, enabling us to study the structure of mortality relationships based on variations among individuals (rather than among broader aggregates). Our empirical work is guided by our prior use of these data to study bioLogical and behavioral influences on infant mortality (Butz, DaVanzo, and Habicht 1982; DaVanzo, Butz, and Habicht 1983; Butz, Habicht, and DaVanzo 1984). In the present study, we focus on variables that strongly influenced infant mortality in our previous study and changed considerably over the 1946- 1975 period. These include: * Socioeconomic factors - mother's education o Sanitation and nutrition variables - household water and sanitation - type and duration of breastfeeding
 - 10 - * Demographic variables - mother's age at the child's birth - whether a short interval preceded the birth - ethnic composition of births We are unable to assess the role of other variables that may have contributed to the decline in infant mortality but are not documented retrospectively in our data--for example, increases in income and expansion of government health programs. Most of the variables documented in our data have changed in such a way that they would contribute to a decline in infant mortality (for example, increases in mothers' education, improvements in household sanitation, and reductions in the proportion of short intervals between births). We assess the relative contributions of these changes. However, the change in one variable that we consider--breastfeeding--would have led to an increase in mortality had other changes not taken place. We assess the extent to which decreases in breastfeeding have slowed the decline in infant mortality. These empirical analyses are presented in Section III, following a description in Section II of our data, the variables we examine, and our analytic methods. The final section summarizes our findings and discusses their implications. II. Data and Methods Data We use data from the 1976-77 Malaysian Family Life Survey (MFLS) (Butz and DaVanzo 1978). This population-based probability-sample survey comprised three rounds in the same panel of households, four months apart, beginning in August 1976. The sample consists of randomly selected private households that
 - 11 - each contained at least one ever-married woman 50 years old or younger at the initial visit. A total of 1262 households (88 percent of the eligible probability sample) completed Round 1 of the survey. These households are contained in 52 primary sampling areas in Peninsular Malaysia, of which 49 were randomly selected; the other three were purposively selected to give additional representation to Indian households and households in fishing communities. The key questionnaire for this analysis is the Round-i Female Retrospective Life History questionnaire (MF2), which includes life events as early as the 1940s for some respondents. This questionnaire includes a complete life history of all of a woman's pregnancies and related events. For each pregnancy, the woman was asked the date and type of outcome. The sample for this analysis is the 5357 live births that occurred between 1941 and 1975 to women in the MFLS sample. 4/ For each of these live births, information was collected on the lengths of unsupplemented and supplemented breastfeeding and whether the child died and, if so, the date of death. The retrospective data also contain a residential history, including characteristics of houses where respondents have lived (such as type of water and toilet sanitation, with whom lived). Another questionnaire, the household roster, documents the mother's birth date, ethnicity, and education level. Variables Considered in the Analysis With this information we have computed the following variables for each live birth to women in our sample. For each, we describe how the variable is measured and why it should affect infant mortality. O Infant mortality: whether the child died in its first year of life.
 - 12 - * Mother's education: years of schooling completed. Higher mother's education is a well-established correlate of lower infant mortality (see review in Cochrane et al. 1980). When its effect on infant mortality is independent of income, it probably reflects mother's knowledge of how to care for children and her awareness and use of appropriate health care services. Since income is not included in our analyses, our education variable will undoubtedly also reflect effects of income, which measures a household's ability to afford the inputs--a good diet, modern medical care--that contribute to good health. * Household water and sanitation: whether the house where the family lived when the child was born had piped water or toilet sanitation. These presumably measure exposure to gastrointestinal disease through contaminated water and to other diseases through lack of personal hygiene. * Breostfeeding: number of months of unsupplemented and supplemented breastfeeding in the first twelve months of life. 5/ Duration of breastfeeding may measure nutritional intake and protection against certain diseases through maternal antibodies. Extent of supplementation or substitution reflects the likelihood of ingestion of pathogens with breastmilk supplements or substitutes. * Interactions of breastfeeding durations and water and sanitation variables. Breastfeeding, especially if unsupplemented, reduces exposure to contaminated water. Hence, the detrimental effects of inadequate water and sanitation should be less the longer breastfeeding lasts. Similarly, breastfeeding should have less of a beneficial effect on survival if hygienic water supplies are available. (See Butz, Habicht and DaVanzo, 1984; and Butz, DaVanzo, and Habicht, forthcoming.)
 - 13 - * Mother's age at child's birth: entered as a spline (piecewise linear) to allow very young (age <18) mothers to exhibit different mortality risks from those of mothers in more prime childbearing years. 6/ Young maternal age is a well-known correlate of higher infant mortality (United Nations 1973; Northman 1974; Puffer and Serano 1975). e Length of preceding birth interval: whether the interval preceding this child's birth was short (<15 mos.) 7/ This variable is associated with infant mortality directly and also indirectly through its effect on birthweight (DaVanzo, Butz, and Habicht, 1983; DaVanzo, Habicht, and Butz, 1984). * Mother's ethnicity: Chinese, Indian, or Malay (the omitted group). Infant mortality rates in Malaysia show consistent ethnic variation (Malaysian Department of Statistics, various years), even when other mortality determinants that are correlated with ethnicity are controlled (DaVanzo, Butz, and Habicht, 1983). 8/ Quality of the MLFS Data on Infant Mortality We have investigated the quality of the MFLS retrospectively reported data on infant mortality and associated life events (Haaga 1983) and find that the secular trend in infant mortality in the MLFS data and the mortality differences between Malays and Chinese are generally similar to those indicated by Malaysian vital statistics. 9/ Figure 2, for example, compares trends in infant mortality rates calculated from the MFLS and Malaysian Vital Statistics. Methods Overview The goal in this paper is to see how well we can explain the infant mortality decline that has occurred in Malaysia since World War II. To do this we use retrospective information on a number of socioeconomic, demographic, sanitation, and nutritional variables that are related to variations in mortality and are alleged to be factors contributing to improvements in child survival. We estimate the relationship between infant mortality and those explanatory variables available in the Malaysian Family Life Survey (MFLS) that both affect infant mortality and have shown sufficient variation over time that they could affect the mortality trend. For example,
 - 17 - we do not include the infant's sex in our analysis because this well-known correlate of mortality differentials exhibits very little systematic variation over time. We also do not consider some proximate determinants, such as birthweight, that affect infant survival, since they largely mediate the effects of other variables such as short birth spacing that are included in the analysis. Another variable we exclude is the calendar year of the child's birth. This variable is highly correlated with variables that have varied systematically over time and might have robbed them of some of their explanatory power had we included it. 13/ We have already discussed above the variables we consider, their definitions, and the reasons for their inclusion. After estimating the relationship of these variables to infant mortality, we see how well the change in these variables can explain the mortality decline that actually occurred. We assess the relative role of changes in each explanatory variable. We also assess whether the structure of the relationship between infant mortality and its determinants has changed over time and assess the importance of these structural changes in explaining the mortality decline. Fixed Structure We first assess the contributions of changes in explanatory variables assuming a fixed structure of coefficients. For this analysis, reported in Table 2, we restrict our sample to births in the years 1956-75 to women under age 30. We restrict the sample in this way in order to hold constant the age range of the sample in each year (see Appendix Table A 3). 14/ This age range will represent the majority of births in any year, given the age pattern of childbearing in Malaysia (see sample sizes in Appendix Table A.2).

Changing Structure The analysis described in the previous subsection assumes that the structure of relationships explaining mortality variations has not changed over time--that changes over time in the explanatory variables are the only reasons for mortality decline. However, over a period of dramatic socioeconomic, demographic, and public health change, it is possible that the structure of the relationships has also changed. Preston (1980) contends that about half of the increase in life expectancy in developing countries between 1940 and 1970 was due to structural change. To assess the role of structural change, we allow for different regression coefficients for two time periods--1946-60 and 1961-75. By extending our time span back to 1946, we cover a longer period than in the fixed structure analysis--a period over which there was a larger decrease in infant mortality. However, in 1946 the oldest woman in the MFLS sample was 20. To define our samples comparably for the 1961-75 period, we restrict our sample in this later period to women who were age 20 or less in 1961. We then follow these two cohorts of women--those aged 20 or less in 1946 and those 20 or less in 1961--over the next 15 years of their lives. Appendix Table A.4 shows the ranges of mothers' ages represented in these two samples. We have pooled these two samples and have estimated both OLS and logit regressions that allow for different coefficients for the two periods. (We do this by interacting each variable with a 1961-75 dummy.) We test whether the 1946-60 and 1961-75 coefficients differ for each variable and find that the OLS and logit estimates often yield different conclusions about
 - 22 - whether the effect of a particular variable differs significantly between the 1946-60 and 1961-75 periods. 19/ We then use the earlier-period structure and the later-period variable values to see how well the earlier structure would predict the mortality decline that actually occurred. We also repeat this exercise "backwards," multiplying the later-period coefficients by the earlier-period variable values to see if the more recent structure can explain mortality in the past. The difference between the actual infant mortality rate in a subperiod and that predicted by that period's values of variables and the other periodl's structure is the portion attributable to structural change. 20/ III. Empirical Analysis Fixed Structure Table 2 presents the results of our analysis that estimate the roles of various variables in explaining infant mortality decline over the 1956-75 period assuming a fixed structure of coefficients. The first two columns show the actual changes in variables that took place between the beginning (1956-60) and end (1971-75) of this period. Between these two subperiods the infant mortality rate of babies born to women younger than age 30 decreased by over half--from 60.6 to 29.9. Over this same period mothers' education increased; piped water and toilet sanitation became more prevalent; fewer births followed a short interval or were to very young women; and relatively more births occurred to Chinese women. Summary and Conclusions This analysis has identified several factors that have contributed to the dramatic decline in infant mortality that has occurred since World War II in Malaysia, as well as one factor that has prevented infant mortality rates from declining even more rapidly. Our main findings are the following: (1) On average, mothers' education more than doubled over the study period and contributed importantly to the decline in their infants' mortality. In addition, the beneficial effect of mothers' educaLion appears to have become stronger over the study period. Hence, further advances in education should lead to further improvements in infants' survival prospects. In another analysis of these data (Khairuddin et al., forthcoming), we also found that education is somewhat more influential in that regard in low-mortality, high- income areas than in the opposite type of areas. It therefore appears that economic development may complement, instead of substitute for, the beneficial effect of mothers' education in promoting infant survival in Malaysia. (2) Improvements in water and sanitation also contributed to the infant mortality decline, especially for babies who were not breastfed. However, unlike education, these influences have become less important over time, especially for babies who are not breastfed. Hence further improvements in water and sanitation, a goal of Malaysia's Rural Environmental Sanitation Programme, can be expected to have smaller relative effects on infant
 - 36 - mortality than did previous improvements. Targetting such improvements on areas where women breastfeed little or not at all, however, will increase their effectiveness in promoting infant survival. (3) The substantial reductions in breastfeeding that have taken place since World War II have kept the infant mortality rate in Malaysia from declining as rapidly as it would have otherwise. In fact, we estimate that, in our sampLe, the detrimental effects on infant survival of the decline in breastfeeding have more than offset the beneficial effects of improvements in water and sanitation. (4) Unlike some recent studies (e.g., Palloni 1981), we find that changes in fertility levels and in the timing and spacing of births have had negligible effect in explaining the decline in infant mortality within the samples we have considered. We have excluded births to older women from our analysis, however, and this may have led to an understatement of the influence of changes in the age pattern of childbearing. (5) Despite the contributions of the variables just discussed, we are unable to explain much of the actual decline in the infant mortality rate by changes in the variables considered here. Our finding, based on micro data on individual births, is similar to Preston's findings based on country aggre gates (1976, 1980) that structural change explains as much or more of mortality decline as do changes in a set of socioeconomic and other variables. 32/ Although we conclude that structural change explains the greater part of the infant mortality decline that occurred, most influences on infant mortality have not changed significantly over time. When a relative risk (logit) model is used, the coefficients of only two variables differ significantly between the periods before and after 1960: the intercept and the coefficient of toilet sanitation (for babies who were not breastfed).
 - 37 - Toilet sanitation had significantly less beneficial influence on infant survival for babies born after 1960 than before. Hence, this structural change has not contributed to the mortality decline. Instead, the explanation for the majority of the mortality decline lies in the influence of factors not considered in this analysis--i.e., in the intercept term. When all variables considered here are held constant, the risk of dying in infancy is much lower after 1960 than before. 33/ What might these other factors be? Although we hesitate to put a label on what we are unable to explain, several possibilities seem likely. One is income growth. Higher incomes enable families to afford better medical care and better nutrition (which reduces the fatality rate from most diseases). Wage incomes (adjusted for cost of living) increased at an average annual rate of 2.4 percent per year in Malaysia over the period considered here (Smith 1983). Since an important share of this income growth was due to increases in education (Smith 1983), however, it is likely that our education variable has already absorbed some of this effect. Improvements in medical and health care may also have contributed to the mortality decline. Since independence in 1957, the Malaysian government has spent increasing amounts of money on programs to combat the major endemic communicable diseases prevalent in the country, 34/ to extend health services to the rural areas, and to provide preventive medical services. Maternal- child health care is one of the largest components of the rural health program. A recent report by the Malaysian government contends that "the rapid fall in child mortality was a direct consequence of these services provided by the Rural Health Programme" (Abu Bakar 1981, p. 257). Many of these programs were begun after 1960 and may well have contributed to the large reduction in the infant mortality rate we find between the 1946-60 and 1961-75 periods. 35/
 - 38 - In conclusion, the greater part of the infant mortality decline in Malaysia is not explained by the factors considered in this analysis. Of the portion that is explained here, increases in mothers' education and improvements in water and sanitation appear to be the most important factors.

 Introduction Considerable excitement has been generated in the health and development field since the mid-1970s by a number of studies suggesting that the pace of mortality decline in the developing world has slowed in the 1960s and 1970s from the rapid improvements of the 1950s. The data bases, mortality indices, and methodology of these studies have varied widely. The most comprehensive analysis has been reported in a series of articles by Preston (1975, 1980, 1983) who used cross-sectional regression analysis to examine relations between expectation of life at birth (and, most recently, infant mortality) and development indicators (per capita income, literary and calorie intake) around 1940 and 1970 (1980) and during the periods 1965-69 and 1975-79 (1983). His conclusion is that the relationships between mortality and the development indicator remained approximately constant over the period, while the rate of improvement attributable to unspecified, exogenous factors declined sharply, from about three years of expectation of life per decade up to the 1960s to only slightly more than one year in the most recent decade. A study of mortality levels and trends by the United Nations (1982) of twenty- four developing countries with reasonably reliable estimates of eo for the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s showed an average annual rate of increase of 0.57 years between the 1950s and 1960s, but of only 0.49 years from the 1960s to the 1970s; the inclusion of a further ten countries for the latter period reduced the annual average gain to 0.45 years. The slowdown is largely accounted for by the observation for Latin America; the countries of Asia show a modest acceleration, those of Africa a modest decline. The slowdown can be partly attributed to some of the countries reaching low mortality levels where gains tend to be slower, but a cross-tabulation of gains by initial life expectancy - 57 -
 - 58 - shows a slowdown for all initial levels except those between 40 and 50 years. Probably the most widely cited study is that of Gwatkin (1980) whose grapeshot argument is hard to summarize, but who presents a large number of indications from diverse sources that the era of unusually rapid developing country mortality declines has at least temporarily come to an end. The object of this paper is not to review the literature, but rather to review the data. In passing, however, it may be noted that Preston's cross- national studies incorporate data of highly variable quality (the United Nations mortality estimates used are for a number of countries little more than informed guesses, and both literacy and calorie availability data are notoriously unreliable), and the cross-sectional approach may give misleading results if the selection of cases by data availability is biased, as it well might be; the stability of the relationships over time argues in their favor, however. The United Nations study covers a limited number of countries selected by data availability in the 1950s; the average is heavily weighted toward Latin American experience, and the availability of data for early periods might well be associated with conditions conducive to rapid mortality decline. Gwatkin's study focuses either on regional aggregates of United Nations mortality estimates (and sometimes expectations) or on the experiences of individual countries or small groups of countries; the latter focus is hazardous since for any period some countries buck the general trend, a case in point being China, where it is now fairly well established (Hill 1983) that mortality was higher at the end of the 1950s, as a result of a severe famine, than at the beginning. Portrayal of the 1950s as a halcyon decade for developing countries is an over-simplification, arrived at by generalizing from a limited number of reasonably reliable observations. However, it is one
 - 59 - thing to qualify the results of studies on the basis of uncertainty or selectivity of observations, but quite another to improve on them. Before going any further, it is necessary to examine the data available and their deficiencies and to clarify what is meant by the pace of mortality decline. Data and Definitions Existing studies of mortality decline in developing countries have focused on expectation of life at birth, eo, and to a lesser extent on the infant mortality rate. Neither of these measures, however, is readily estimated by current demographic methodology, an important consideration given that only a handful of developing countries have accurate vital registration systems that obviate the necessity for the application of such methodology. Two more technically appropriate measures have been used in this study: (1) the expectation of life at age five for females, ef, adequately estimated even from moderately incomplete vital registration data using recently developed methods for comparing deaths by age with population by age (there is no evidence that estimates for females are in general preferable to estimates for males; estimates for females have been used for the sake of simplicity, and also because female age distributions tend to be less distorted by migration and age-selective under coverage); and (2) the probability of dying by age five, q(5), often adequately estimated from reports of women concerning the survival of their children. Though the two measures together effectively determine eo, for many countries only one of the two is available, so the separation into two age ranges maximizes the use of the most reliable available indicators. Thus, for sub-Saharan Africa no adequate estimates of adult mortality exist, while for China, estimates of child mortality are largely conjectural.
 - 60 - The next question is what should be regarded as the pace of mortality decline. The most obvious measures are the average annual increase in e5f and average annual decline in q(5). Figures 1 and 2 show the trends in these two measures for a group of many developed countries in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.  - 90 - Summary and Conclusions The analysis presented in this paper has been limited to developing countries with mortality estimates that are regarded as reasonably reliable. Developed countries have been excluded altogether, though it would be interesting to see whether their mortality trends reveal patterns similar to those for developing countries. Observations for a total of fifty-three countries, seventeen in the developing Americas, twenty-one in sub-Saharan Africa, and fifteen in Asia, Oceania and North Africa are included at some point or another in the analysis; in terms of the total populations of these groupings, most of the Americas, somewhat less than half of sub-Saharan Africa, and less than a quarter of Asia, Oceania and North Africa are included. The conclusions drawn must therefore be regarded as tentative at best, with the caveat that they apply only to the countries under observation. Limiting the analysis to relatively reliable observations, at the cost of broader representativeness, was preferred to the alternative strategy of improving representativeness at the cost of reliability. An additional cost of the insistence on reliability is a lack of very recent observations. Two mortality measures have been used: female life expectancy at age 5, e5, to represent adult mortality, and the probability of dying by age 5 for both sexes to represent child mortality. A transformation of ef, T(ef ) the rate of gain relative to an upper asymptote taken as 80 years, has also been used to allow for any deceleration in absolute rates of change at high life expectancies. Population weighted average rates of change in both e5f and 5 T(ef) support the view that rates of adult mortality decline were somewhat 5 slower from the 1960s to the 1970s than from the 1950s to the 1960s; on an untransformed basis, the average rate of improvement for the later period was
 - 91 - 71 percent of that for the earlier period for the Americas, and 82 percent for Asia, Oceania and North Africa, corresponding values for the transformed variable being 75 percent and 85 percent respectively. No observations for sub-Saharan Africa were included. Birth weighted average rates of change in q(5) suggest also some deceleration in the rate of decline of child mortality in the Americas and sub-Saharan Africa (88 percent and 69 percent respectively in the later period of their rates of change in the earlier period), but a substantial acceleration (169 percent) for Asia, Oceania and North Africa. It is interesting to note that the weighted average rates of decline are quite similar across regional groupings, though the declines in q(5) for the Asia grouping from the 1960s to the 1970s, and for sub-Saharan Africa from the 1950s to the 1960s, are faster than elsewhere. This comparison of rates of mortality decline suggests that if there has been any deceleration in the rates, it has not been very large and has affected Asia less than the Americas and sub-Saharan Africa. Regression analysis has been used to examine the relationships between the mortality indicators on the one hand and development indicators, specifically per capita income and proportions with no education, on the other in order to see whether any slowdown in mortality decline could be accounted for in terms of a general slowdown in development. Pooled regressions combining observations for the 1950s and 1960s and 1960s and 1970s, together with an explicit time variable (years since 1945) gave generally rather satisfactory results, though the fits for sub-Saharan Africa were poor. Though the time variable was never significant, it implied a trend toward lower mortality independent of income and education from the 1950s to the 1960s for the Americas and Africa, but no such trend for Asia from the 1950s to the 1960s, or for any region from the 1960s to the 1970s. The coefficients

 - 95 - stalls in mortality decline in particular countries have not occurred, nor that such stalls should not be a cause for concern for those countries. Argentina and Uruguay show virtually no recent mortality decline at levels of life expectancy where developed countries still showed reasonable rates of decline; mortality decline in Mauritius has slowed sharply, and possibly reversed in Sri Lanka; Bangladesh suffered increasing mortality in the early 1970s, as did China around 1960. Perhaps we should not have been surprised; developing countries now have mortality levels way below those of developed countries at similar levels of development, and mortality reductions may be more fragile in the face of wars, natural disasters, and disease evolutions. The next decade may be particularly difficult in tropical Africa, with the appearance of malaria strains resistant to the prophylactic and even therapeutic use of chloroquine. There does not, however, seem to be any critical point where further progress is particularly difficult; China, with probably low general development scores, has reduced mortality to very low levels without any apparent stall; countries of Central America and the Caribbean have reduced their mortality to levels below those of Argentina and Uruguay, again without any apparent stall; low mortality levels have been achieved in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Korea without reversal. It would seem that there is no need for global concern, but rather attention to the specific countries where mortality decline has stalled in order to identify and rectify the factors responsible.

 Abstract The period from the 1930 to the 1960s was one of unprecedented mortality decline in developing countries. In cross sectional analyses of factors which may be responsible for this rapid improvement in survivorship, Preston (1975, 1980) demonstrated that only about 30 percent of the improvement could be explained by measurable aspects of social and economic development such as income, literacy, and nutrition. A more sluggish pace of mortality decline apparently characterized the decade that began in the middle of the 1960s. The purpose of this paper is to carry out an analysis similar to the earlier ones but concentrated on this later period. The study finds that, contrary to previous periods, the social and economic variables of income, literacy, and nutrition were the dominating factors in explaining mortality decline during the 1965-69 to 1975-79 decade. This greater relative role does not result from faster improvements in social and economic conditions during the recent period or from an increased responsiveness of mortality to social and economic variables. Rather, the exoghenous factors appear to have operated with sharply reduced intensity in the more recent period.  Introduction This paper is an attempt to update results reported in two earlier papers regarding the role of socioeconomic factors in world-wide mortality declines since the 1930s. Preston (1975) demonstrated that the relationship between life expectancy at birth (eo) and per capita income (in constant dollars) had shifted between the 1930s and the 1960s. A country at a particular level of national income per capita was estimated to have a level of life expectancy at birth that was, on average, 9.7 years higher in the 1960s than it would have been in the 1930s at that same level of income. This shift was clearly attributable to factors other than measured income gains, although it is possible that measured gains are biased indicators of true gains. In an attempt to identify the contribution of advances in literacy and nutrition to this apparent shift, Preston (1980a) added these variables to income in regression equations estimated with data on 36 countries around 1940 and on 120 countries around 1970. For less developed countries (LDCs), the shift in the relationship between 1940 and 1970 was estimated to be 8.8 years after these variables were introduced along with income (Preston 1980a: 307). Thus, literacy and nutritional gains were responsible for relatively little of the shift. This new shift factor accounted for exactly half of the 17.6 year gain in life expectancy that was estimated by the World Health Organization (WHO) to have occurred between these approximate dates. However, the estimate of the structural shift did not include data on China, whereas China was included in the WHO data on LDC life expectancy gains. Since Chinese progress was remarkably rapid and since China represents 30 percent of total LDC population and is likely to have gained 30 years in e0 between these - 103 -
 - 104 - dates (Banister and Preston 1981), the remaining LDCs would have gained an average of only 12.3 years in e0. So the 8.7 year shift would have representecl 71 percent of the total gain for the LDCs except China. These results seem sufficient to show that mortality trends are not dominated by a simple mechanistic input-output relation between mortality and other prominently observed features of the economy and society. While relations between mortality and these development indicators are very tight at both the household and the national levels, there is clearly room for other factors to play a role, and these factors seem to have been dominant in producing change during the period from the 1930s to 1970. What is the nature of these factors? Schultz (1979) quite correctly cautions that the above exercises help to rule out certain explanations, or at least to define their explanatory power more precisely, but are not helpful in defining the factors that were actually operative. Preston (1980a) suggests that anti-malarial campaigns were a leading source of the shift, since they were cheap to implement (and often subsidized by international donors), widespread, and evidently quite effective. But he notes that slight changes in statistical procedures have a large impact on the estimated size of Malaria's contributions. Subsequently, he suggested without convincing demonstration that anti-malarial activities were the largest source of the gains, followed by immunization campaigns and improvements in personal health practices (Preston, 1980b). Later work, though cross-sectional, would seem to underscore the importance! of personal health practices. Mosely (1983) argues that government health care programs have been largely ineffective because of poor administra- tion and biases toward inappropriate western-style medical technology. A more persuasive explanation of recent mortality improvement in Kenya, he argues, is
 - 105 - advances in literacy. In this matter he has much support. Mothers' educational attainment or literacy has repeatedly emerged as one of the strongest and most persistent correlates of child mortality in LDCs (Caldwell 1979, Schultz 1979, Cochrane 1980, Farah and Preston 1982, Wolfe and Behrman 1982, Mensch et. al. 1983). While gains in literacy per se cannot account for the shift in mortality/development relations, the importance of education in cross-sectional relations points to a major role for personal health care knowledge and practices in child mortality. Both knowledge and practice can be affected by many factors other than formal schooling, and one could postulate that there has been a general diffusion of health practices as their power becomes demonstrated and as communication systems improve. The importance of ethnic group membership in explaining child mortality variation, even after many socioeconomic factors have been controlled, is further suggestive evidence of the importance of child care practices, which presumably vary considerably among ethnic groups (Mensch et. al. 1983). According to this latter explanation, mortality advance is largely a product of widespread diffusion of knowledge, rather than of socioeconomic advance or of enlightened government programs, Obviously, these three processes are not mutually exclusive and each process is likely to have contributed to the gains that have been made, with their relative contributions likely to change from period to period. Mortality Declines Since 1965 There have been many suggestions that the pace of mortality improvement in LDCs has slowed since the middle of the 1960s (Hansluwka 1975, Gwatkin 1981). Such a decline would coincide with a period of lagging
 - 106 - commitments of international aid for health purposes, especially for anti- malarial programs (Preston 1980a). In a careful investigation of this question, the United Nations (1982a) concluded that, for the 24 LDCs that could supply reasonably reliable mortality information in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s the average gain in life expectancy was .57 years per calendar year between the 1950s and 1960s and .49 years per calendar year between the 1960s and 1970s. Relaxing the restriction that a country have data for three periods and admitting countries with only two observations, the study finds that the avierage pace of change declined from .61 to .43 years per year between the two decades. The relatively small decline in the rate of mortality adivance was essentially confined to Latin American countries, and some of the decline there was attributed to several countries' having reached high levels of life expectancy where rates of advance are normally slow. The mildly pessimistic picture that emerges for the selectively few LDCs with adequate data requires emendation for developing countries as an aggregate. As noted earlier, China has had a remarkably rapid mortality decline, and much of it was concentrated in the period since the early 1960s. Recently released age distributions from the 1953 and 1964 censuses suggest that life expectancy at birth for the intercensal period was extremely low, probably in the range of 38-46 years. 1/ The Great Leap Forward disasters of 1959-61 may have been largely responsible for this low level. By 1974, life expectancy had risen to about 63 years, representing a gain of about 1.33 years per calendar year from a figure of 42 years at the center of the intercensal period. A wide variety of procedures was used to investigate this issue. In all cases a mortality indicator was used as the dependent variable in a cross- national regression analysis that includes data from LDCs and developed countries (MDCs). In all cases the set of independent variables included some transformation of the percentage of adults who were literate, gross domestic product per capita in constant dollars, and the excess of per capita daily calories supplied above 1500 (approximately the amount required to meet minimum metabolic demands). For example, it is likely that, by 1982 when the UN data were published, fewer than half of the developing countries would have produced direct information on mortality conditions during 1975-79. What factors are responsible for this slowdown in the pace of mortality decline from "exogenous" factors? Since these factors themselves have not been identified with any precision, it is impossible to demarcate clearly their varying roles. Of the two major factors that have been suggested--government programs and the person-to-person diffusion of good health knowledge and practices--the former seems more capable of abruptly changing in intensity. As noted earlier, there is some evidence that government programs have lagged. Part of the reason is that some of the easier gains, especially from anti-malarial programs in Asia and Latin America, were already registered before 1965. Malaria in Africa is a far less tractable problem, and the rate of progress has been very slow (Molineaux 1983). International aid for health from the largest donor, USAID, has declined considerably in real terms, partly out of fear of the population growth consequences of continued mortality decline. Although some of the easiest gains have already been scored, there is no question that a battery of programmatic approaches, demonstrably successful in carefully controlled settings, are still available for implementation. 1/ In considering ways to advance health, however, governments should not neglect 1/ The literature here is vast. One of the striking results of this paper, confirming earlier results at both the micro and macro levels, is the extremely powerful role of literacy in determining a population's level of mortality. The coefficient of literacy in life expectancy regressions is very robust, .2, suggesting that moving from 0 to 100 percent literate would increase eo by about 20 years, ceteris paribus; alternatively, it would reduce the infant mortality rate by about 130/1000. Since universal literacy can be achieved for about 1-4 percent of national income per capita (Lewis 1968), it is clear that programs to advance education--especially, judging from micro studies, female education--are potentially one of the most cost-effective ways to improve mortality in developing countries, although the effects obviously operate with a lag of, on average, about 20 years. doc.repnme: Quantitative studies of mortality decline in the developing world
doc.abstracts: The infant mortality rate has declined dramatically in Peninsular Malaysia since World War II. This study uses individual-level retrospective data on infant mortality and its correlates (from the Malaysian Family Life Survey) to examine possible reasons for this decline. One important factor has been the substantial increase in mothers' education. Improvements in water and sanitation also played a role; however, the reduction in breastfeeding that has taken place in Malaysia has kept the infant mortality rate from declining as rapidly as it would have otherwise. This paper shows that the detrimental effects of reduced breastfeeding have more than offset the beneficial effects of improvements in water and sanitation. In a majority of the cases, infant mortality decline is not explained by changes in the variables considered here, but is due to factors not investigated here - most likely, increases in income and improvements in medical and health care.
